fields.label_text:
Foundling Hospital Chalice, Paten and Alms Dish

The chalice, paten and alms dish were used during Holy Communion to serve the consecrated wine and bread and to collect donations. 

They were an anonymous gift to the Foundling Hospital in London. The chalice is engraved with the hospital’s coat of arms, designed by William Hogarth, in which Nature and Britannia support a shield with a foundling. Its motto is ‘Help’. The paten bears the crest of a lamb with an olive branch.

The Foundling Hospital was started by Captain Thomas Coram in 1746 to provide
a home and education for orphans and abandoned babies. The governors wanted
the children to be instructed in the ‘Principles of Religion and Morality’ and to go to church on Sundays. They were also to be reminded of the ‘lowness of their Condition, that they may early imbibe the Principles of Humility and Gratitude to their Benefactors’.

London, England, 1753–4; by Fuller White
(active 1734–75). Silver gilt
Lent by the Coram Family in the care of the Foundling Museum

fields.descriptive_line: A silver-gilt alms dish presented by an anonymous gentleman to the London Foundling Hospital Chapel, supplied by Fuller White and made in London in 1753.

fields.name: Gifts to Charity
fields.venue: Sacred Silver and Stained Glass Galleries, the Victoria and Albert Museum

fields.label:
Foundling Hospital Chalice, Paten and Alms Dish

The chalice, paten and alms dish were used during Holy Communion to serve the consecrated wine and bread and to collect donations.

Lent by the Coram Family in the care of the Foundling Museum [22/11/2005]
fields.location: Sacred Silver & Stained Glass, room 83, case 2C
fields.marks: Maker's mark for Fuller White and London Hall Mark, Sterling Silver Mark and Date letter for 1753. Engraved with the Coat of Arms of the Foundling Hospital designed by William Hogarth.
fields.public_access_description:

They were an anonymous gift to the Foundling Hospital in London. The chalice is engraved with the hospital’s coat of arms, designed by William Hogarth, in which Nature and Britannia support a shield with a foundling. Its motto is ‘Help’. The paten bears the crest of a lamb with an olive branch.

The Foundling Hospital was started by Captain Thomas Coram in 1746 to provide a home and education for orphans and abandoned babies. The governors wanted the children to be instructed in the ‘Principles of Religion and Morality’ and to go to church on Sundays. They were also to be reminded of the ‘lowness of their Condition, that they may early imbibe the Principles of Humility and Gratitude to their Benefactors’.

fields.bibliography: Nicholls & Wray, History of the Foundling Hospital, 1935
fields.credit: Lent by the Coram Family in the care of the Foundling Museum
fields.history_note:
The almsdish, one of a pair, was presented to the Foundling Hospital, London by an anonymous gentleman with a set of communion plate consisting of two chalices and patens, one of the dishes was made in 1749, the other in 1753.

Historical significance: Hospital governors recognised the importance of religion in educating and nurturing those for whom they cared. As there 'was no Place of Public Worship to which the Children and Servants of the Hospital could conveniently resort' the Governors resolved 'to erect a Chapel adjoining to their Hospital in Lamb's Conduit Fields being earnestly desirous that the children in their care should be early instructed in the Principles of Religion and Morality'. 'They should be taught the Catechism used by the Church of England and heard to read such parts of the holy scripture as are most suitable for their understanding.' The Chapel was erected by public subscription with a contribution of £2000 from King George II and the first stone laid on 1st May 1747. The chapel opened in 1753 with a special performance of music by George Frederick Handel. The altarpiece 'The offering of the Wise Men' was painted by Andrea Casali. The pulpit was given by the architect Henry Keene, The children sat in the galleries on the north and south sides of the chapel, the subscribers and supporters of the charity sat in the main body of the chapel and placed their contribution in the almsdishes
fields.historical_context_note:
Gifts to Charity
Public benefactions were seen as evidence of the donor’s faith. In 18th-century London, leading citizens founded institutions to assist the poor, sick and isolated. Prevention was better than a cure, and in 1758 the Asylum for Female Orphans was founded to prevent prostitution. In the same year the Magdalen Hospital was established to reform repentant prostitutes.

Hospital governors recognised the importance of religion in educating and nurturing those for whom they cared. Regular communion was considered part of the healing process. In poorhouses parish officers saw that communion was celebrated and prayer books distributed.

The Foundling Hospital was founded by Captain Thomas Coran in 1746 to provide a home and education for orphans and abandoned babies. The governors wanted the children to be instructed in the 'Principles of Religion and Morality' and to go to church on Sundays and other days appointed for public worship. They were also to be reminded of the 'lowness of their Condition, that they may early imbibe the Principles of Humility and Gratitude to their Benefactors'
